alfredsnippet.snippet:
(cont'd)

"... Without the aid of such ideas, Darwin would soon have choked on the volume of ‘facts’ he had managed to collect within weeks of embarking on his grand project. As this suggests, for all the dangers involved in having a-priori beliefs about the way in which nature works, such assumptions are indispensable if sense is to be made of data derived from even the most apparently precise of experiments. Experimental or field evidence nearly always contains some degree of ambiguity. Order must therefore be imposed on it. If we did not do this, progress would at best be tortuously slow; at worst, impossible."
alfredsnippet.name: Phys.org Post - Theories Usually Precede the Large-Scale Accumulation of Facts - 3
